title: Two Sum
description:
Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target.

You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice.

You can return the answer in any order.

examples.input: nums = [2,7,11,15], target = 9
examples.explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].

examples.input: nums = [3,2,4], target = 6
examples.explanation: Because nums[1] + nums[2] == 6, we return [1, 2].

examples.input: nums = [3,3], target = 6
examples.explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 6, we return [0, 1].

constraints: 2 <= nums.length <= 10â´
-10â¹ <= nums[i] <= 10â¹
-10â¹ <= target <= 10â¹
Only one valid answer exists.

title: Valid Parentheses
description:
Given a string s containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '[' and ']', determine if the input string is valid.

An input string is valid if:
1. Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets.
2. Open brackets must be closed in the correct order.
3. Every close bracket has a corresponding open bracket of the same type.

examples.explanation: The string has matching parentheses.
All brackets are properly closed and in the correct order.
Mismatched bracket types.
Brackets are not closed in the correct order.

constraints: 1 <= s.length <= 10â´
s consists of parentheses only '()[]{}'

title: Merge Two Sorted Lists
description:
You are given the heads of two sorted linked lists list1 and list2.

Merge the two lists into one sorted list. The list should be made by splicing together the nodes of the first two lists.

Return the head of the merged linked list.

examples.explanation: The merged list contains all elements in sorted order.

examples.input: list1 = [], list2 = []
examples.explanation: Both lists are empty.

examples.input: list1 = [], list2 = [0]
examples.explanation: First list is empty, return second list.

constraints: The number of nodes in both lists is in the range [0, 50]
Both list1 and list2 are sorted in non-decreasing order

title: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
description:
You are given an array prices where prices[i] is the price of a given stock on the iáµ—Ê° day.

You want to maximize your profit by choosing a single day to buy one stock and choosing a different day in the future to sell that stock.

Return the maximum profit you can achieve from this transaction. If you cannot achieve any profit, return 0.

examples.explanation: Buy on day 2 (price = 1) and sell on day 5 (price = 6), profit = 6-1 = 5. Note that buying on day 2 and selling on day 1 is not allowed because you must buy before you sell.
In this case, no transactions are done and the max profit = 0.

constraints: 1 <= prices.length <= 10âµ
0 <= prices[i] <= 10â´

title: Valid Palindrome
description:
A phrase is a palindrome if, after converting all uppercase letters into lowercase letters and removing all non-alphanumeric characters, it reads the same forward and backward. Alphanumeric characters include letters and numbers.

Given a string s, return true if it is a palindrome, or false otherwise.

examples.input: s = "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama"
examples.explanation: "amanaplanacanalpanama" is a palindrome.

examples.input: s = "race a car"
examples.explanation: "raceacar" is not a palindrome.
s is an empty string "" after removing non-alphanumeric characters. Since an empty string reads the same forward and backward, it is a palindrome.

constraints: 1 <= s.length <= 2 * 10âµ
s consists only of printable ASCII characters

title: Reverse Linked List
description: Given the head of a singly linked list, reverse the list, and return the reversed list.

examples.explanation: The list is reversed from 1->2->3->4->5 to 5->4->3->2->1.

examples.input: head = [1,2]
examples.explanation: The two-node list is reversed.

examples.input: head = []
examples.explanation: Empty list remains empty.

constraints: The number of nodes in the list is the range [0, 5000]

title: Invert Binary Tree
description:
Given the root of a binary tree, invert the tree, and return its root.

Inverting a binary tree means swapping the left and right children of every node in the tree.

examples.explanation: The tree is inverted by swapping left and right children at every level.
Simple inversion of a three-node tree.

examples.input: root = []
examples.explanation: Empty tree remains empty.

constraints: The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [0, 100]

title: Valid Anagram
description:
Given two strings s and t, return true if t is an anagram of s, and false otherwise.

An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

examples.input: s = "anagram", t = "nagaram"
examples.explanation: Both strings contain the same characters with the same frequencies.

examples.input: s = "rat", t = "car"
examples.explanation: The strings have different characters.

constraints: 1 <= s.length, t.length <= 5 * 10â´
s and t consist of lowercase English letters

title: Binary Search
description:
Given an array of integers nums which is sorted in ascending order, and an integer target, write a function to search target in nums. If target exists, then return its index. Otherwise, return -1.

You must write an algorithm with O(log n) runtime complexity.

examples.explanation: 9 exists in nums and its index is 4.
2 does not exist in nums so return -1.

constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 10â´
-10â´ < nums[i], target < 10â´
All the integers in nums are unique
nums is sorted in ascending order

title: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
description: Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

examples.input: s = "abcabcbb"
examples.explanation: The answer is "abc", with the length of 3.

examples.input: s = "bbbbb"
examples.explanation: The answer is "b", with the length of 1.

examples.input: s = "pwwkew"
examples.explanation: The answer is "wke", with the length of 3. Notice that the answer must be a substring, "pwke" is a subsequence and not a substring.

constraints: 0 <= s.length <= 5 * 10â´
s consists of English letters, digits, symbols and spaces

title: 3Sum
description:
Given an integer array nums, return all the triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that i != j, i != k, and j != k, and nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0.

Notice that the solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.

examples.explanation:
nums[0] + nums[1] + nums[2] = (-1) + 0 + 1 = 0.
nums[1] + nums[2] + nums[4] = 0 + 1 + (-1) = 0.
nums[0] + nums[3] + nums[4] = (-1) + 2 + (-1) = 0.
The distinct triplets are [-1,0,1] and [-1,-1,2].
The only possible triplet does not sum up to 0.
The only possible triplet sums up to 0.

constraints: 3 <= nums.length <= 3000
-10âµ <= nums[i] <= 10âµ

title: Group Anagrams
description:
Given an array of strings strs, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.

An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

examples.input: strs = ["eat","tea","tan","ate","nat","bat"]
examples.explanation: The strings are grouped by their sorted character sequences.

examples.input: strs = [""]
examples.explanation: Single empty string forms one group.

examples.input: strs = ["a"]
examples.explanation: Single character string forms one group.

constraints: 1 <= strs.length <= 10â´
0 <= strs[i].length <= 100
strs[i] consists of lowercase English letters

title: Maximum Subarray
description: Given an integer array nums, find the subarray with the largest sum, and return its sum.

examples.explanation: The subarray [4,-1,2,1] has the largest sum 6.

examples.input: nums = [1]
examples.explanation: The subarray [1] has the largest sum 1.
The subarray [5,4,-1,7,8] has the largest sum 23.

constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 10âµ

title: Merge Intervals
description: Given an array of intervals where intervals[i] = [startáµ¢, endáµ¢], merge all overlapping intervals, and return an array of the non-overlapping intervals that cover all the intervals in the input.

examples.explanation: Since intervals [1,3] and [2,6] overlap, merge them into [1,6].
Intervals [1,4] and [4,5] are considered overlapping.

constraints: 1 <= intervals.length <= 10â´
intervals[i].length == 2
0 <= startáµ¢ <= endáµ¢ <= 10â´

title: Climbing Stairs
description:
You are climbing a staircase. It takes n steps to reach the top.

Each time you can either climb 1 or 2 steps. In how many distinct ways can you climb to the top?

examples.explanation: There are two ways to climb to the top: 1. 1 step + 1 step, 2. 2 steps.
There are three ways to climb to the top: 1. 1 step + 1 step + 1 step, 2. 1 step + 2 steps, 3. 2 steps + 1 step.

title: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree
description:
Given the root of a binary tree, return its maximum depth.

A binary tree's maximum depth is the number of nodes along the longest path from the root node down to the farthest leaf node.

examples.input: root = [3,9,20,null,null,15,7]
examples.explanation: The tree has a maximum depth of 3.

examples.input: root = [1,null,2]
examples.explanation: The tree has a maximum depth of 2.

constraints: The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [0, 10â´]

title: Linked List Cycle
description:
Given head, the head of a linked list, determine if the linked list has a cycle in it.

There is a cycle in a linked list if there is some node in the list that can be reached again by continuously following the next pointer. Internally, pos is used to denote the index of the node that tail's next pointer is connected to. Note that pos is not passed as a parameter.

Return true if there is a cycle in the linked list. Otherwise, return false.

examples.explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 1st node (0-indexed).

examples.input: head = [1,2], pos = 0
examples.explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 0th node.

examples.input: head = [1], pos = -1
examples.explanation: There is no cycle in the linked list.

constraints: The number of the nodes in the list is in the range [0, 10â´]
-10âµ <= Node.val <= 10âµ
pos is -1 or a valid index in the linked-list

title: Number of Islands
description:
Given an m x n 2D binary grid grid which represents a map of '1's (land) and '0's (water), return the number of islands.

An island is surrounded by water and is formed by connecting adjacent lands horizontally or vertically. You may assume all four edges of the grid are all surrounded by water.

examples.explanation: There is one island formed by the connected '1's.
There are three separate islands.

constraints: m == grid.length
n == grid[i].length
grid[i][j] is '0' or '1'

title: Contains Duplicate
description: Given an integer array nums, return true if any value appears at least twice in the array, and return false if every element is distinct.

examples.explanation: The value 1 appears twice.
All elements are distinct.
Multiple values appear more than once.

constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 10âµ
-10â¹ <= nums[i] <= 10â¹

title: Product of Array Except Self
description:
Given an integer array nums, return an array answer such that answer[i] is equal to the product of all the elements of nums except nums[i].

The product of any prefix or suffix of nums is guaranteed to fit in a 32-bit integer.

You must write an algorithm that runs in O(n) time and without using the division operation.

examples.explanation: The zero makes most products zero.

constraints: 2 <= nums.length <= 10âµ
The product of any prefix or suffix of nums is guaranteed to fit in a 32-bit integer

title: Reverse Integer
description:
Given a signed 32-bit integer x, return x with its digits reversed. If reversing x causes the value to go outside the signed 32-bit integer range [-2Â³Â¹, 2Â³Â¹ - 1], then return 0.

Assume the environment does not allow you to store 64-bit integers (signed or unsigned).

examples.explanation: The digits are reversed from 123 to 321.
Negative sign is preserved while reversing digits.
Trailing zeros are removed after reversal.

constraints: -2Â³Â¹ <= x <= 2Â³Â¹ - 1

title: Unique Paths
description:
There is a robot on an m x n grid. The robot is initially located at the top-left corner (i.e., grid[0][0]). The robot tries to move to the bottom-right corner (i.e., grid[m - 1][n - 1]). The robot can only move either down or right at any point in time.

Given the two integers m and n, return the number of possible unique paths that the robot can take to reach the bottom-right corner.

The test cases are generated so that the answer will be less than or equal to 2 Ã— 10â¹.

examples.explanation: There are 28 unique paths from top-left to bottom-right.
From top-left corner, there are 3 ways to reach bottom-right: 1. Right -> Down -> Down, 2. Down -> Down -> Right, 3. Down -> Right -> Down

title: House Robber
description:
You are a professional robber planning to rob houses along a street. Each house has a certain amount of money stashed, the only constraint stopping you from robbing each of them is that adjacent houses have security systems connected and it will automatically contact the police if two adjacent houses were broken into on the same night.

Given an integer array nums representing the amount of money of each house, return the maximum amount of money you can rob tonight without alerting the police.

examples.explanation: Rob house 1 (money = 1) and then rob house 3 (money = 3). Total amount you can rob = 1 + 3 = 4.
Rob house 1 (money = 2), rob house 3 (money = 9) and rob house 5 (money = 1). Total amount you can rob = 2 + 9 + 1 = 12.

constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 100

title: Course Schedule
description:
There are a total of numCourses courses you have to take, labeled from 0 to numCourses - 1. You are given an array prerequisites where prerequisites[i] = [aáµ¢, báµ¢] indicates that you must take course báµ¢ first if you want to take course aáµ¢.

For example, the pair [0, 1], indicates that to take course 0 you have to first take course 1.

Return true if you can finish all courses. Otherwise, return false.

examples.input: numCourses = 2, prerequisites = [[1,0]]
examples.explanation: There are a total of 2 courses to take. To take course 1 you should have finished course 0. So it is possible.

examples.input: numCourses = 2, prerequisites = [[1,0],[0,1]]
examples.explanation: There are a total of 2 courses to take. To take course 1 you should have finished course 0, and to take course 0 you should also have finished course 1. So it is impossible.

constraints: 1 <= numCourses <= 2000
0 <= prerequisites.length <= 5000
prerequisites[i].length == 2
0 <= aáµ¢, báµ¢ < numCourses
All the pairs prerequisites[i] are unique

title: Coin Change
description:
You are given an integer array coins representing coins of different denominations and an integer amount representing a total amount of money.

Return the fewest number of coins that you need to make up that amount. If that amount of money cannot be made up by any combination of the coins, return -1.

You may assume that you have an infinite number of each kind of coin.

examples.input: coins = [1,2,5], amount = 11
coins = [2], amount = 3
examples.explanation: Amount 3 cannot be made with only coins of denomination 2.

examples.input: coins = [1], amount = 0
examples.explanation: Zero coins are needed for amount 0.

constraints: 1 <= coins.length <= 12
1 <= coins[i] <= 2Â³Â¹ - 1
0 <= amount <= 10â´
